message_1: A spacecraft travels toward a black hole at a velocity of 0.8c. At this velocity, what is the time dilation factor experienced by the spacecraft crew? How much time will pass on the spacecraft clock before it crosses the event horizon of the black hole, assuming an observer's clock at a safe distance from the black hole records that 1 hour has passed?
message_2:
To calculate the time dilation factor experienced by the spacecraft crew, we can use the time dilation formula from the theory of special relativity:

t' = t / sqrt(1 - v^2/c^2)

where t' is the time experienced by the moving observer (the spacecraft crew), t is the time experienced by the stationary observer (at a safe distance from the black hole), v is the velocity of the moving observer (0.8c), and c is the speed of light.

Plugging in the values, we get:

t' = t / sqrt(1 - (0.8c)^2/c^2)
t' = t / sqrt(1 - 0.64)
t' = t / sqrt(0.36)

The time dilation factor is the reciprocal of the square root of 0.36:

Time dilation factor = 1 / sqrt(0.36) ≈ 1.6667

Now, we need to find out how much time will pass on the spacecraft clock before it crosses the event horizon of the black hole, assuming an observer's clock at a safe distance from the black hole records that 1 hour has passed.

Using the time dilation factor, we can find the time experienced by the spacecraft crew:

t' = t / time dilation factor
t' = 1 hour / 1.6667 ≈ 0.6 hours

So, approximately 0.6 hours (36 minutes) will pass on the spacecraft clock before it crosses the event horizon of the black hole.
